Bi-MOF-derived BiPS4/C armored with conductive Ni-HHTP: A dual MOF-mediated strategy for polysulfide suppression in sodium storage Ming Yue Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation a Wen Chen Methodology Data curation b Yanzhe Sheng Investigation Data curation a Yanhe Xiao Writing – review & editing Supervision a Baochang Cheng Writing – review & editing Supervision a Shuijin Lei Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a School of Physics and Materials Science, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, Jiangxi, China School of Physics and Materials Science Nanchang University Nanchang Jiangxi 330031 China School of Physics and Materials Science, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, Jiangxi, China b China State Key Laboratory of Marine Resource Utilization in South China Sea, Hainan Provincial Key Laboratory of Research on Utilization of Si-Zr-Ti Resources, Hainan University, Haikou 570228, Hainan, China China State Key Laboratory of Marine Resource Utilization in South China Sea Hainan Provincial Key Laboratory of Research on Utilization of Si-Zr-Ti Resources Hainan University Haikou Hainan 570228 China China State Key Laboratory of Marine Resource Utilization in South China Sea, Hainan Provincial Key Laboratory of Research on Utilization of Si-Zr-Ti Resources, Hainan University, Haikou 570228, Hainan, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Dual-MOF-engineered BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP core–shell architecture synergistically combines conductive Ni-HHTP armor with Bi-MOF-derived carbon matrix, achieving superior sodium storage performance through simultaneous conductivity improvement, polysulfide confinement and volume buffering during conversion-alloying processes. Metal phosphosulfides (MPS x ), especially BiPS4, have emerged as promising anode candidates for sodium-ion batteries, distinguished by distinctive multinary redox chemistry, open tunnel-type structure, and high theoretical capacity (> 1000 mAh g−1). However, their practical implementation is fundamentally limited by polysulfide dissolution/shuttling and structural instability during prolonged cycling. Herein, we develop a groundbreaking two-stage metal–organic framework (MOF)-engineered compositing strategy through which Bi-MOF-derived BiPS4/C pillars are robustly armored with conductive Ni-HHTP (HHTP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene) nanorods. Density functional theory calculations reveal that this design achieves dual functionality: increased carrier density for enhanced charge transport dynamics and effective polysulfide adsorption to inhibit dissolution. The fabricated BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite delivers remarkable electrochemical properties, including high initial charge/discharge specific capacities of 1063.6/1181.3 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and outstanding long-term stability with 99.2% capacity retention after 2000 cycles at 2 A g−1. Such superb performance stems from the perfect synergy of the inherent high-capacity redox behavior of BiPS4, the buffering effect of MOF-derived carbon, and the conductivity, adsorption sites and mechanical resilience of Ni-HHTP. This work establishes a new design paradigm for MPS x materials, demonstrating how to simultaneously overcome conductivity limitations and shuttle effects in conversion-type electrodes. Keywords Metal phosphosulfides BiPS4 MOF engineering Polysulfides Sodium-ion batteries 1 Introduction Amidst escalating concerns over global warming, energy crises, and air pollution, the development of high-energy-density, eco-friendly energy storage systems has become a critical strategy to mitigate energy shortages and environmental degradation [1,2]. Among various electrochemical energy storage technologies, alkali metal-ion batteries have garnered significant attention as a highly promising solution. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), celebrated for their high energy density, long cycle life, and environmental compatibility, dominate advanced energy storage applications [3–5]. However, their widespread deployment is impeded by limited lithium reserves, high costs, and safety concerns. In contrast, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) present a compelling alternative, offering several advantages, such as lower cost, enhanced safety, superior low-temperature performance, and sustainability, making them particularly well-suited for large-scale energy storage and low-speed electric vehicles [6,7]. Despite these benefits, the capacity and cycling stability of conventional hard carbon anodes in SIBs remain significant challenges [8,9]. To position SIBs as a competitive technology in the future energy market, continuous structural optimization and the development of novel high-performance materials are imperative. In recent years, MPS x compounds have attracted great interest as promising anode materials for SIBs due to their tunable bandgap, expanded interlayer spacing, and versatile elemental composition [10–12]. These materials enable quite high theoretical capacities through combined conversion and multi-step alloying reactions during sodium storage [13–15]. Various MPS x compounds, including FePS3 [16], NiPS3 [17], MnPS3 [18], and ZnPS3 [19], have been investigated as SIB anodes, demonstrating impressive electrochemical performance.For instance,Kim et al. reported a graphene-coated ZnPS3 anode synthesized via mechanical grinding, achieving a reversible capacity of 421 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 A g−1 [19]. Similarly, Yin et al. developed Sb0.7Bi0.3PS4 by partially substituting Bi3+ for Sb3+ in SbPS4, which delivered an initial discharge capacity of 831 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 through multi-step alloying and sulfide conversion reactions [20]. Nevertheless, the practical application of MPS x anodes always suffers from rapid capacity fading, primarily attributed to severe volume fluctuations during Na+ ions intercalation/deintercalation processes. To address this issue, strategies such as particle size reduction, porous architecture design, and the incorporation of inactive buffer phases have been explored [21,22]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and their derivatives stand out as particularly effective modifiers due to their high surface area, tunable porosity, and ability to enhance ion diffusion and electronic conductivity [23,24]. The carbon frameworks derived from MOF pyrolysis can further improve structural stability and accommodate volume changes, thereby boosting the performance of MPS x anodes [25,26]. For example, Yue et al. utilized Sn-MOF as a template to synthesize SnPS3@C, leveraging its porous structure and carbon framework to substantially enhance Na+ ion migration rate and cycling stability [27]. A critical challenge in MPS x -based sodium storage lies in the formation of soluble polysulfide intermediates (e.g., Na2S4 and Na2S2), which severely degrade battery performance [28]. The notorious polysulfide shuttle effect leads to irreversible active material loss, accelerated self-discharge, diminished Coulombic efficiency, and shortened cycle life, posing both performance limitations and safety concerns [29]. While hierarchical porous carbon materials can improve conductivity and partially confine polysulfides, their nonpolar surfaces exhibit only weak van der Waals interactions with polar polysulfide species, resulting in inadequate long-term efficacy [30,31]. To overcome these limitations, researchers have pursued innovative material design strategies such as multidimensional spatial structuring and advanced composite engineering. A representative breakthrough was demonstrated by Ren et al., who developed a Co/Ni bimetal-doped MOF core–shell structure encapsulating sulfur particles, which provided spatial confinement and catalytic sites to suppress polysulfide shuttling [32]. Conductive metal–organic frameworks (CMOFs) have shown great promise in energy storage and catalysis thanks to their unique structural and functional properties [33]. In alkali metal-ion batteries, CMOFs are particularly attractive because they combine high capacity, excellent rate capability, and superior cycling stability [34]. Their ability to enhance ion/electron transport and chemically adsorb polysulfides makes them ideal for improving battery performance [35–37]. For example, Wang et al. demonstrated that Ni-HHTP, a highly conductive MOF, drastically strengthens polysulfide adsorption and redox kinetics [38]. The Ni-HHTP coating not only exhibits long-term stability but also enables ion screening, polysulfide adsorption, and multi-step catalytic transformation, representing a significant advancement in alkali metal-ion battery technology. Can et al. directly employed Ni3(HITP)2 as a sulfur host in Li-S batteries (S@Ni3(HITP)2), achieving remarkable electrochemical performance through physical confinement and chemical adsorption of polysulfides [39]. Inspired by these advances, we designed a porous core–shell BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite through a dual-MOF-mediated tactic. The synthesis involved first preparing BiPS4/C via synchronous carbonization and phospho-sulfurization of a Bi-MOF precursor, followed by in situ growth of nanorod-shaped Ni-HHTP on its surface. This innovative architecture strategically integrates Bi-MOF-derived BiPS4/C with conductive Ni-HHTP, synergistically combining their respective advantages in polysulfide confinement, charge transport and cycling stability: (i) Dual polysulfide confinement: the combined action of Ni/O active sites in Ni-HHTP and the carbon skeleton from Bi-MOF ensures comprehensive polysulfide suppression; (ii) Charge transport optimization: the π-d conjugated network in Ni-HHTP establishes electron “superhighways”, while the carbon matrix provides rapid Na+ ions diffusion channels; (iii) Cycling stability improvement: the core–shell design, featuring MOF-derived active material core and Ni-HHTP-armored shell, significantly enhances structural integrity during electrochemical cycling. As a result, the fabricated BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode exhibits outstanding Na+ storage performance, presenting important implications for next-generation energy storage systems. 2 Results and discussion To elucidate the mechanisms underlying the enhanced conductivity and polysulfide adsorption in BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP, first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed to examine the electronic structures of BiPS4 and BiPS4@Ni-HHTP, as well as their interactions with Na2S4/Na2S2. The MOF-derived carbon present in both BiPS4/C and BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composites primarily functions to enhance macroscopic conductivity of the electrode and provide physical adsorption sites for polysulfides. These carbon-mediated effects, while crucial for overall electrochemical performance, operate independently from the fundamental interfacial electronic interactions between BiPS4 and Ni-HHTP. Consequently, the construction of simplified computational models focusing solely on BiPS4 and BiPS4@Ni-HHTP remains fully justified for investigating the intrinsic materials interactions responsible for performance enhancement. As illustrated in Fig. 1 a, the total density of states (DOS) analysis reveals that BiPS4@Ni-HHTP exhibits a significantly higher DOS value of 10.59 eV at the Fermi level compared to pristine BiPS4 (4.81 eV) and Ni-HHTP (1.32 eV). The BiPS4@Ni-HHTP composite shows notably increased DOS near the Fermi level compared to its individual components. This enhancement primarily arises from three key interfacial phenomena: (1) charge redistribution between the materials, where electrons transfer from Bi/P orbitals in BiPS4 to Ni-3d or ligand π* orbitals in Ni-HHTP; (2) formation of new hybridized electronic states between Ni-3d and Bi-6p/S-3p; and (3) consequent broadening of energy bands. These interfacial interactions overcome the intrinsic electronic limitations of the separate components (BiPS4′s wide bandgap and Ni-HHTP's localized 3d electrons), yielding “1 + 1 > 2” synergistic effects with improved conductivity and tunable electronic states. This pronounced increase suggests a substantial enhancement in carrier density and charge transport kinetics within the composite. Fig. 1b presents the structural configurations of BiPS4, BiPS4@Ni-HHTP, and Ni-HHTP across different crystal facets. The computational results reveal distinct polysulfide adsorption characteristics among the materials, with BiPS4@Ni-HHTP showing remarkably strong adsorption energies of −1.78 eV for Na2S4 and −3.11 eV for Na2S2, which markedly surpass those of BiPS4 (−0.29 eV for Na2S4 and −1.00 eV for Na2S2) and Ni-HHTP (−1.20 eV for Na2S4 and −2.70 eV for Na2S2) (Fig. 1c). These results clearly indicate that the porous architecture and surface functional groups of Ni-HHTP provide additional active sites for polysulfide adsorption, substantially improving binding stability. This unique composite structure serves as both a physical barrier against Na-pS x dissolution and an effective suppressor of the polysulfide shuttle effect. Further analysis reveals the Ni-HHTP coating induces prominent charge accumulation at the BiPS4@Ni-HHTP interface, facilitating efficient charge transfer and enhancing sodium storage capability (Fig. 1d). Comparative analysis of Na+ adsorption manifests that BiPS4@Ni-HHTP exhibits a lower adsorption energy (−2.29 eV) than BiPS4 (−1.78 eV) and Ni-HHTP (−1.90 eV), confirming that the Ni-HHTP modification not only strengthens sodium ion adsorption but also accelerates reaction kinetics. These synergistic effects collectively contribute to the superior electrical conductivity, high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE), and exceptional cycling stability of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite. To quantitatively assess the polysulfide adsorption capability, some complementary experiments were carried out by respectively introducing equivalent amounts ofNi-HHTP, pure BiPS4, BiPS4/C, and BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP into Na2S4 solutions (Fig. S1a). After 12 h of adsorption, solutions containing Ni-HHTP and BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP exhibit complete discoloration from deep yellow to colorless, indicating their rapid and efficient Na-pS x adsorption capacity. Notably, the BiPS4/C solution exhibits moderate color attenuation compared to pure BiPS4, revealing the additional polysulfide adsorption capability contributed by the Bi-MOF-derived carbon matrix. The UV–vis absorption spectroscopy results of these solutions can further corroborate the aforementioned observations. As illustrated in Fig. S1b, the absorption peak at 265 nm is characteristic of Na2S4. Evidently, the Na2S4 solution with Ni-HHTP exhibits the lowest absorbance, followed by BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP, and then BiPS4/C, unequivocally demonstrating that both Ni-HHTP and the Bi-MOF-derived carbon corporately enhance the adsorption capacity for Na2S4. To address the intrinsic sluggish kinetics and polysulfide (Na2S4 and Na2S2) dissolution challenges in BiPS4, a dual-MOF-mediated core–shell structure composite was rationally designed.This architecture consisted of a Bi-MOF-derived BiPS4/C core encapsulated by a conductive Ni-HHTP armor shell, as illustrated in the synthesis schematic (Fig. 2 a). The synthesis involved three key steps: First, uniform hexagonal prism shaped Bi-MOF precursor was synthesized via hydrothermal synthesis (Fig. S2); Second, Bi-MOF was converted into BiPS4/C through simultaneous phospho-sulfurization and carbonization, while preserving the pillar morphology with an average diameter of about 4 μm (Fig. S3). However, the resulting BiPS4/C pillars had a roughened surface due to the protruding growth of BiPS4 crystals. Third, the conductive Ni-HHTP MOF layer was grown on BiPS4/C through solvothermal treatment, forming a completely wrapped “armor”. The field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images verify the successful integration of Ni-HHTP nanorods into a continuous coating around BiPS4/C (Fig. 2b–d). This unique architecture ensures efficient Na+ transport and electrolyte penetration. The SEM images ofpure Ni-HHTP sample further confirm its nanorod morphology (Fig. S4), whereas those of pure BiPS4 sample reveal its irregular bulk structure (Fig. S5). The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping images display the homogeneous distribution of all constituent elements (Bi, P, S, Ni, C, and O) (Fig. 2e). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image further demonstrates that Ni-HHTP nanorods uniformly encapsulate BiPS4/C forming a ∼150 nm thick coating layer (marked with red lines) (Fig. 2f). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP reveals well-defined lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.36 and 0.53 nm (Fig. 2g), corresponding to the (204) and (200) crystal planes of the orthorhombic BiPS4. Furthermore, the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns exhibit distinct diffraction rings indexed to the (020), (004), (220), (224), (314)/(040), (240)/(008), and (244) crystal planes, corroborating the crystalline structure of BiPS4 phase (Fig. 2h) [22,40]. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were employed to analyze the phase composition of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP and related materials. The synthesized Bi-MOF precursor exhibits diffraction patterns consistent with literature reports (Fig. S6a) [41]. For the Ni-HHTP MOF sample, the characteristic peaks at 13.7° and 27.1° correspond to the (210) and (001) crystal planes, respectively (Fig. 3 a) [42]. In the XRD spectra of all BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP, BiPS4/C and pure BiPS4 samples, the distinct diffraction peaks at 16.0° (020), 16.7° (200), 23.2° (220), 24.2° (024), 24.7° (204), 29.6° (224), 36.5° (240), and 38.6° (404) can be observed (Fig. 3a and Fig. S6b) [40], matching perfectly with the reference patterns of orthorhombic BiPS4 (PDF#01-071-0364). As shown in Fig. 3a, the coexistence of the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni-HHTP and BiPS4 in the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite sample validates the successful incorporation of crystalline BiPS4 with Ni-HHTP. Raman spectroscopic analysis reveals noticeable vibration characteristics of BiPS4 that differ significantly from transition metal phosphosulfides (Fig. 3b and Fig. S7). The Reman spectrum of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP can be categorized into three characteristic regions based on atomic mass differences: Bi-related modes below 90 cm−1, S-related vibrations between 90 and 420 cm−1, and P-associated modes above 420 cm−1. Specifically, in the low-frequency region, the Raman peaks at 60.3 and 87.3 cm−1 are attributed to the shear vibrations of Bi3+ between layers [40]. In the intermediate frequency region, the Ag modes at 140.5, 210.4 and 241.6 cm−1, along with the B2g mode at 193.5 cm−1, originate from different vibrational modes of sulfur atoms. Particularly noteworthy are the Ag mode at 270.5 cm−1, corresponding to the in-plane stretching vibrations of sulfur atoms coordinated with Bi, and the Ag mode at 410 cm−1 corresponding to the characteristic “breathing” mode of S atoms in (PS4)3− groups [43]. The high-frequency region features a broad Raman peak at 548.2 cm−1, arising from the phosphorus atom motions and in-plane stretching vibrations (Ag mode). Besides, the stretching mode of Ni–O bonds in Ni-HHTP appears near 525 cm−1, confirming the successful encapsulation of the BiPS4/C surface by Ni-HHTP [44]. Furthermore, the carbon matrix characterization reveals two prominent band features: the defect-induced D band at 1350 cm−1 and the graphitic G band at 1560 cm−1. The calculated ID/IG ratio of 1.06 for BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP falls between BiPS4/C (1.08) and Ni-HHTP (0.90), indicating that the Bi-MOF-derived carbon framework introduces substantial structural defects. These defects serve as additional active sites, enhancing the electrochemical performance of the composite materials. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was employed to investigate the elemental composition and chemical states of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite. The survey spectrum clearly confirms the presence of all expected elements including Bi, P, S, Ni, O, and C (Fig. S8a), validating successful material synthesis. In the high-resolution Bi 4f spectrum (Fig. 3c), the characteristic doublet peaks at 162.8 eV (Bi 4f 5/2) and 157.4 eV (Bi 4f 7/2) are observed alongside corresponding S 2p peaks at 162.5 eV (S 2p 1/2) and 161.8 eV (S 2p 3/2) [45]. The high-resolution P 2p spectrum is deconvoluted into three peaks (Fig. 3d): two broad peaks at 133.6 eV (P 2p 1/2) and 132.7 eV (P 2p 3/2) related to P–S bonds, together with an additional peak at 131.8 eV attributed to P–P bonds [46,47]. In the Ni 2p core-level spectrum (Fig. S8b), the two peaks at 870.1 and 852.9 eV are assigned to Ni 2p 1/2 and Ni 2p 3/2 of the Ni–O bonds, accompanied by two satellite peaks at 874.2 and 856.4 eV. The core spectrum of C 1 s is fitted into three components (Fig. S8c), corresponding to CC (284.8 eV), CO (286.1 eV), and CC (281.8 eV) bonding configurations. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurements were performed to characterize the specific surface area and porous characteristics of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite. The observed type IV isotherm with pronounced hysteresis confirms its mesoporous nature (Fig. 3e), which facilitates electrolyte penetration. The BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite exhibits a significantly increased surface area (17.3 m2 g−1) compared to BiPS4/C (4.9 m2 g−1) and pure BiPS4 (2.8 m2 g−1), owing to the coating of high-surface-area Ni-HHTP (72.8 m2 g−1) (Fig. S9). Notably, the in situ formation of bulk BiPS4 within the porous framework reduces the specific surface area relative to the original Bi-MOF precursor (398.3 m2 g−1). Moreover, the pore size distribution of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP reveals that the majority of pores are concentrated in the range of 7–45 nm. Thus, the high specific surface area and porous core–shell architecture of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP not only enhance electrolyte infiltration and expedite ion/electron transport but also effectively accommodate the volume fluctuations during conversion-alloying reactions. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted under air atmosphere (25–900°C, 10°C min−1) to quantify the contents of carbon and Ni-HHTP within the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite (Fig. 3f). It is observed that below 300°C, the weight loss ratio of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP is significantly higher than that of pure BiPS4 and BiPS4/C. This enhanced mass loss should be attributed to the material's greater specific surface area and well-developed porous structure, which facilitate increased water adsorption capacity. At the terminal temperature, the mass losses of Ni-HHTP, BiPS4, BiPS4/C, and BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP are recorded at 77.9 wt%, 16.9 wt%, 21.4 wt%, and 36.3 wt%, respectively. These results establish that the MOF-derived carbon and Ni-HHTP contents in the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite are 4.0 wt% and 26.4 wt%, respectively. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis (0.1 mV s−1, 0.01–3.0 V) was performed to elucidate the electrochemical reaction mechanism of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode. The initial four cycles reveal distinct redox features corresponding to complex conversion-alloying reactions, as shown in Fig. 4 a. During the initial cathodic scan, pronounced reduction peaks at 1.84 and 1.77 V are attributed to the insertion of Na+ ions into BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP, resulting in the formation of Na x BiPS4 [22]. The reduction peak at 0.96 V signifies the gradual transformation of Na x BiPS4 into elemental Bi and P, which is associated with the multi-step conversion reactions of sulfides to form Na2S and the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) [20]. Conversely, the oxidation peak at 2.13 V corresponds to the reversible conversion reaction of Na2S to generate S [40]. Additionally, multiple reduction peaks at 0.43, 0.25, and 0.05 V indicate that Bi and P undergo multi-step alloying reactions to form Na3Bi and Na3P, respectively [27,48]. Correspondingly, three oxidation peaks at 0.08, 0.61, and 1.85 V denote the multi-step dealloying reactions of Na3Bi and Na3P to revert to Bi and P. In subsequent cycles, the overlapping redox peaks of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode underscore its excellent electrochemical reversibility. Comparative CV profiles of BiPS4/C and pure BiPS4 electrodes confirm that this multi-step mechanism is intrinsic to the BiPS4-based materials, while the Ni-HHTP coating and Bi-MOF-derived carbon matrix enhance reaction kinetics and cycling stability (Fig. S10). To assess the superior sodium-ion storage capability of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode, systematic galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) tests were conducted. As revealed in Fig. 4b, at a current density of 0.1 A g−1, the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode delivers initial charge/discharge specific capacities of 1063.6/1181.3 mAh g−1, with an impressive initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 90.0%. Remarkably, the initial specific capacities and ICE of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode considerably surpass those of BiPS4/C (902.9/1104.3 mAh g−1, 81.8%) and pure BiPS4 (625.5/1207.8 mAh g−1, 51.8%) electrodes (Fig. S11). The enhanced initial capacity and Coulombic efficiency of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP primarily stem from the MOF-mediated dual synergistic effects: both the MOF-derived carbon matrix and the outer Ni-HHTP layer effectively adsorb polysulfides, inhibiting their dissolution, while the unique encapsulated architecture facilitates the formation of a more stable SEI, thereby minimizing irreversible sodium loss. Due to kinetic constraints in the diglyme electrolyte, the redox-active sites of the Ni-HHTP electrode cannot efficiently couple with the electrolyte, leading to its low specific capacity. After 50 cycles at 0.1 A g−1, the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode retains a high specific capacity of 794.1 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention rate of 67.3% (Fig. 4c), dramatically outperforming BiPS4/C (51.1%) and pure BiPS4 (27.3%). The BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode exhibits significantly enhanced capacity retention owing to the effective polysulfide confinement by its Ni-HHTP protective layer, whereas both pure BiPS4 and BiPS4/C electrodes undergo rapid capacity decay caused by polysulfide dissolution and shuttle effects during initial cycles. Comparative SEM images of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode before and after cycling demonstrate perfect structural integrity with no observable morphological degradation (Fig. S12), confirming the robustness of this composite design. Additionally, the SEM images of the Ni-HHTP, pure BiPS4, and BiPS4/C electrodes after cycling are shown in Fig. S13. Except for the Ni-HHTP electrode, the morphologies of the pure BiPS4 and BiPS4/C electrodes have experienced varying degrees of fragmentation. The rate performance of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP, BiPS4/C, and pure BiPS4 electrodes was further investigated (Fig. 4d). The BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode exhibits outstanding discharge specific capacities of 855.3, 766.6, 700.9, 631.1, 603.6, and 551.4 mAh g−1 at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5.0 A g−1. Remarkably, when returning to 0.1 A g−1, the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode regained a specific capacity of 753.5 mAh g−1, highlighting the structural resilience imparted by the synergistic combination of the multifunctional Ni-HHTP protective layer and Bi-MOF-derived carbon skeleton in effectively buffering volume expansion during multi-step conversion-alloying reactions. The BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode exhibits well-maintained voltage plateaus and highly consistent GCD curve profiles across progressively increasing current densities (Fig. 4e), clearly demonstrating excellent electrochemical reversibility and robust structural stability enabled by the Ni-HHTP layer. Comparative analysis with previously reported Bi-based anodes (Fig. 4f and Table S1) demonstrates the superior sodium storage capacity of the fabricated BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite electrode [20,22,40,49–52].More impressively, the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode also presents excellent long-term cyclability, retaining 577.3 mAh g−1 (99.2% capacity retention) after 2000 cycles at 2.0 A g−1 (Fig. 4g). While BiPS4/C (79.3% capacity retention after 2000 cycles) prevails over pure BiPS4 (55.9% capacity retention after 600 cycles) in cycling stability due to the structural reinforcement from MOF-derived carbon, it exhibits much inferior capacity and retention rate compared to BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite‌. After undergoing 2000 charge–discharge cycles, the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode retains its initial morphological characteristics without noticeable structural deterioration, highlighting outstanding cycling durability (Fig. S14). Even at a high current density of 5.0 A g−1, the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode still achieves an encouraging reversible capacity of 432.2 mAh g−1 after 5000 cycles (Fig. S15). Crucially, this outstanding performance originates from the synergistic integration of Ni-HHTP armor and MOF-derived carbon, which mitigates volume changes in BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP, catalyzes polysulfide conversion, and accelerates electrochemical reaction kinetics. To elucidate the enhanced electrochemical kinetics of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode, its charge storage behavior was systematically investigated through pseudocapacitive analysis and galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) measurements, with parallel studies on BiPS4/C and pure BiPS4 electrodes for comparison. The CV curves of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode at varying scan rates (0.2–2.0 mV s−1) maintain consistent redox features, demonstrating excellent electrochemical reversibility and minimal polarization (Fig. 5 a). Typically, the relationship between scan rate (v, mV s−1) and peak current (i, mA) can be used to distinguish between diffusion-controlled (b = 0.5) and pseudocapacitance-controlled (b = 1.0) processes, as described by Eq. (1) [53]. The b-values for the characteristic redox peaks 1–3 of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode are calculated to be 0.74, 0.92, and 0.98 (Fig. 5b), respectively, which all fall between 0.5 and 1, suggesting that the electrochemical reactions of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode are predominantly governed by pseudocapacitive behavior. To quantify the pseudocapacitive contribution of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode, Eq. (2) was applied. At a scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1, the capacitive contribution reaches 90.9% (Fig. 5c), revealing that the electrochemical behavior of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode is primarily dominated by pseudocapacitive contribution at high current densities. Additionally, the pseudocapacitive contribution of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP (65.8%–92.5%) is markedly higher than that of BiPS4/C (59.2%–85.8%) and pure BiPS4 (45.2%–77.1%) at 0.2–2.0 mV s−1 (Fig. 5d and Fig. S16). The enhanced surface-controlled storage is attributable to the dual MOF-engineered architecture‌, which plays a decisive role in enabling the excellent rate capability of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode. The sodium ion diffusion coefficient ( D Na + ) serves as a vital kinetic parameter governing the electrochemical reaction rates [54]. As anticipated, GITT analysis reveals that the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode exhibits higher D Na + values (5.0 × 10−7–5.0 × 10−5 cm2 s−1) during both discharge and charge processes, significantly surpassing those of BiPS4/C (1.3 × 10−7–3.2 × 10−5 cm2 s−1) and pure BiPS4 (4.0 × 10−8–2.0 × 10−5 cm2 s−1) electrodes (Fig. 5e, f and Eq. (3). The superior Na+ diffusion observed in BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP stems from the synergistic integration of its conductive Ni-HHTP layer and MOF-derived carbon matrix, demonstrating significantly improved electrochemical kinetics relative to both pure BiPS4 and BiPS4/C electrodes. Fig. 5g illustrates the in situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tracking for the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode during the initial sodiation/desodiation process to uncover the dynamic interfacial evolution. Upon discharging from the open-circuit voltage to 2.0 V, the charge transfer resistance (R ct) increases from 5.6 to 7.1 Ω, which is primarily attributed to the sodium ion concentration polarization effect near the electrode surface. This polarization phenomenon becomes more pronounced with the continuous charge accumulation during the discharge process. When discharging to approximately 1.8 V, a sharp decrease in R ct from 7.1 to 5.5 Ω is observed. This can be explained by the massive sodium ion diffusion and intercalation into the active material driven by the electrochemical potential gradient, which effectively alleviates the sodium ion accumulation at the interface, thereby reducing the charge transfer resistance. As the discharge proceeds to around 0.6 V, the occurrence of alloying reactions requires substantial sodium ions to form alloy products, leading to a notable increase in sodium ion concentration at the interface. Consequently, the charge transfer resistance increases while the sodium ion diffusion coefficient decreases. Fully discharging to 0.01 V results in a decrease of R ct to 2.8 Ω, where the electrode material exhibits its maximum sodium ion diffusion rate. During the subsequent desodiation process, the overall electrochemical impedance of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode shows a rising trend, consistent with the GITT measurement results. It should be noted that conspicuous impedance peaks can be found at approximately 0.61 V and 2.13 V during desodiation, which are mainly ascribed to the sodium ion accumulation effect resulting from the multi-step desodiation reactions of alloy compounds and polysulfides. The EIS fitting results reveal a remarkable decrease in R ct of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode from 24.53 Ω (initial state) to 3.54 Ω after 10 cycles, eventually reaching 2.52 Ω after 50 cycles (Fig. S17). This gradual reduction in impedance highlights the crucial role of the Ni-HHTP layer in enhancing electron transfer and sodium-ion diffusion kinetics. The distribution of relaxation time (DRT) was determined by fitting the in situ EIS data of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode. The equivalent circuit model (R s + [(R ct + Wo)//CPE]), which explicitly couples charge transfer and diffusion impedance, provides a more accurate description for the heterogeneous interfacial kinetics in the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode. As shown in Fig. 5h, both the R SEI and R ct of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP during cycling are far lower than those of BiPS4/C and pure BiPS4 (Fig. S18). In addition, under open-circuit voltage conditions, BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP remains the smaller R ct than BiPS4/C and pure BiPS4. Furthermore, the integrated impedance values derived from the DRT profiles (Fig. 5i) reveal that the R s, R SEI, and R ct of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP consistently maintain very low levels throughout the entire charge–discharge process. This remarkable difference in electrochemical performance can be attributed to the enhanced charge transport efficiency and improved structural stability resulting from the Ni-HHTP conductive shell and MOF-derived carbon, which facilitate faster ion diffusion and more stable electrode–electrolyte interface during cycling. (1) i = av b (2) l o g ( i ) = b l o g ( v ) + l o g ( a ) (3) D Na + = 4 π τ m B V M M B S 2 Δ E S Δ E t 2 , τ ≪ L 2 D Na + The sodiation/desodiation mechanism of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode was systematically investigated using in situ XRD analysis (Fig. 6 a, b). At the open-circuit voltage, the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode exhibits characteristic diffraction peaks at 15.9°, 16.7°, 21.4°, and 29.5°, corresponding to the (020), (200), (114), and (224) planes of orthorhombic BiPS4, respectively. During the discharge process, these peaks progressively shift due to Na+ ion intercalation, forming Na x BiPS4 with expanded lattice spacing [22,40]. When the discharge process continues until the BiPS4 diffraction peaks completely disappear, the newly emerged peaks observed at 30.8° and 33.2° can be assigned to Na2S4 (PDF#01-071-0516), while the peak at 40.1° corresponds to Na2S2 (PDF#01-081-1764),indicating the initiation of conversion reactions. As the discharge proceeds to 1.1 V, the appearance of new diffraction peaks at 38.9° (Na2S, PDF#00-023-0441) and 27.2° (Bi, PDF#00-044-1246) confirms the progressive conversion of sodium polysulfides into Na2S. Upon complete sodiation, the distinct characteristic peaks of Na3Bi (PDF#00-004-0351) and Na3P (PDF#00-004-0764) are observed at 20.9°/32.8° and 36.0°, respectively. These results demonstrate that BiPS4 undergoes the complete conversion into Na3Bi, Na3P, and Na2S upon full sodiation. Conversely, during the desodiation process, the diffraction peaks of Na3P and Na3Bi gradually weaken and eventually disappear, while the characteristic peak of metallic Bi re-emerges at 27.2°. The absence of P diffraction peaks can be attributed to its low crystallinity, making its weak signal submerged within that of the Ni-HHTP matrix [20,40]. As desodiation continues, the peaks of Na2S also gradually weaken and finally vanish, accompanied by the appearance of a new peak at 23.1°, corresponding to the (222) plane of S (PDF#00-008-0247). Ex situ HRTEM and SAED analyses were employed to confirm the phase transformations of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode during the initial charge–discharge cycle. At a discharged potential of 1.5 V, the HRTEM image clearly identifies two distinct sets of lattice fringes: spacings of 0.27 and 0.29 nm matching the (312) and (213) crystallographic planes of Na2S4, and a 0.31 nm spacing corresponding to the (102) plane of Na2S2 (Fig. S19). When fully discharged to 0.01 V, HRTEM analysis reveals distinct lattice fringes with d-spacings of 0.23, 0.38, 0.25, and 0.42 nm, corresponding to the (220) and (111) planes of Na2S, the (110) plane of Na3P, and the (101) plane of Na3Bi, respectively (Fig. 6c). The SAED patterns further confirm the existence of these phases, with diffraction rings clearly indexed to Na3P, Na3Bi and Na2S (Fig. 6d). These results provide direct evidence for the multi-step conversion and alloying reaction mechanism during discharge. At the fully charged state, HRTEM analysis shows clear lattice spacings of 0.24, 0.28, and 0.33 nm, which can be assigned to the (317) and (044) planes of S and the (012) plane of Bi, respectively (Fig. 6e). Combined with the corresponding SAED patterns in Fig. 6f, these observations provide conclusive evidence of irreversible phase transformations during the initial electrochemical cycle. The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) image and corresponding EDS elemental mapping images demonstrate the uniform spatial distribution of Bi, P, S, C, Ni and sodiation products (Na) in the fully sodiated BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP (Fig. 6g). Therefore, the electrochemical sodiation/desodiation mechanism of the BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode can be elucidated through the following reaction pathways (Fig. 6h and Eqs. (4)–(8)). Sodiation process (4) BiPS4 + xNa+ + xe− → Na x BiPS4 (5) Na x BiPS4 + (14 − x) Na+ + (14 − x) e− → 4Na2S + Na3P + Na3Bi Desodiation process (6) Na3P ↔ 3Na+ + 3e− + P (7) Na3Bi ↔ 3Na+ + 3e− + Bi (8) Na2S ↔ 2Na+ + 2e− + S The outstanding half-cell performance of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP prompted us to evaluate its practical application in full-cell configurations. Na3V2(PO4)3/C (NVP/C), distinguished by its remarkable Na superionic conductor crystal structure, excellent electrochemical activity, and high theoretical energy density, has emerged as a highly promising cathode material for SIBs [55]. The superior rate performance of the NVP/C cathode in half-cells provides a solid foundation for optimizing full-cell performance (Fig. S20). Based on the half-cell performance of both electrodes, the NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell was constructed, comprising a BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP anode and an NVP/C cathode, with the assembly schematic depicted in Fig. 7 a. According to the initial charge–discharge curves of the NVP/C cathode and BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP anode in half-cells (Fig. 7b), the operating voltage range for the NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell was determined to be 1.0 to 3.6 V. As shown in Fig. 7c, the GCD curves of the NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell at 0.1 C (1 C = 117 mA g−1) exhibits high consistency, indicating excellent electrochemical reversibility. Notably, the ICE of the NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell reaches 97.4%, with initial charge and discharge capacities of 110.9 and 108.0 mAh g−1. Fig. 7d reveals that the gradual increase in discharge specific capacity during the 0.1 C cycling process can be ascribed to the activation of the NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell, with the specific capacity reaching 98.5 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles. The rate performance of the NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell is illustrated in Fig. 7e. Upon increasing the current density from 0.1 to 2.0 C, the slight capacity drops of merely 16.4 and 22.6 mAh g−1 are observed at 1.0 and 2.0 C, respectively. Especially, when the current density is restored to 0.1 C, the full cell maintains a specific capacity of 99.1 mAh g−1, representing an exceptional capacity retention of 90.0%. Furthermore, after 300 cycles at 1.0 C, the NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell delivers a reversible capacity of 85.8 mAh g−1, with a capacity retention rate of 80.3% (Fig. 7f), demonstrating high cycling stability. To validate its practical application, the assembled NVP/C||BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP full cell was used to power light-emitting diode (LED) display. As shown in the inset of Fig. 7f, the “I♡NCU” pattern composed of white LED bulbs is successfully illuminated. These results highlight the significant potential of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP for applications in small portable devices. 3 Conclusions In summary, a novel dual-MOF engineering strategy is successfully developed for the fabrication of high-performance BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite, which demonstrates to be a superb SIBs anode material. The product features in situ grown Ni-HHTP conductive MOF nanostructures on the surface of Bi-MOF-derived BiPS4/C, creating a unique synergistic architecture that integrates high conductivity, rich porosity, and large surface area. The BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP electrode exhibits exceptional electrochemical performance, such as high specific capacity, excellent rate capability, and outstanding cycling stability. These superior properties originate from the dual MOF-mediated synergistic effects, where the highly conductive Ni-HHTP network and Bi-MOF-derived carbon matrix work in concert to: (i) overcome the intrinsic limitations of BiPS4 (poor conductivity and polysulfide shuttling), while (ii) providing mechanical stability against substantial volume variations during conversion-alloying processes through their dual-protection mechanism. DFT calculations further substantiate that the Ni-HHTP modification significantly enhances both electronic conductivity and polysulfide anchoring capability of BiPS4. The remarkable anode performance of BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP establishes this ‌dual MOF-mediated strategy as a promising paradigm for developing high-rate and long-term durable MPS x -based energy storage systems, demonstrating great potential for practical implementation in advanced SIBs. coredata.dc:description: Metal phosphosulfides (MPS x ), especially BiPS4, have emerged as promising anode candidates for sodium-ion batteries, distinguished by distinctive multinary redox chemistry, open tunnel-type structure, and high theoretical capacity (> 1000 mAh g−1). However, their practical implementation is fundamentally limited by polysulfide dissolution/shuttling and structural instability during prolonged cycling. Herein, we develop a groundbreaking two-stage metal–organic framework (MOF)-engineered compositing strategy through which Bi-MOF-derived BiPS4/C pillars are robustly armored with conductive Ni-HHTP (HHTP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene) nanorods. Density functional theory calculations reveal that this design achieves dual functionality: increased carrier density for enhanced charge transport dynamics and effective polysulfide adsorption to inhibit dissolution. The fabricated BiPS4/C@Ni-HHTP composite delivers remarkable electrochemical properties, including high initial charge/discharge specific capacities of 1063.6/1181.3 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and outstanding long-term stability with 99.2% capacity retention after 2000 cycles at 2 A g−1. Such superb performance stems from the perfect synergy of the inherent high-capacity redox behavior of BiPS4, the buffering effect of MOF-derived carbon, and the conductivity, adsorption sites and mechanical resilience of Ni-HHTP. This work establishes a new design paradigm for MPS x materials, demonstrating how to simultaneously overcome conductivity limitations and shuttle effects in conversion-type electrodes.
